Re ''A Warning From Putin and Schroder,'' by Josef Joffe (Op-Ed, June 20):

The American grand strategy must figure out how best to protect the United States' lead in world affairs. Mr. Joffe alludes to the correct path: pursue hegemony, but not brazenly. Political-science literature mentions that balancing occurs against those states viewed as aggressive revisionists.

The paradox is that the United States leads the international system but, as Mr. Joffe suggests, is beginning to take actions that may overturn that system. Pursuit of certain military capabilities overshoots what China, Russia and our allies perceive as reasonable modernization.
Prudent statecraft with emphasis on diplomacy can lead to a durable Pax Americana. It is not necessarily the outcome others will resist, but the path through which the objective is pursued.
The writer is an associate professor of political science, University of Cincinnati.
